channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Chilcot Report on Iraq War Offers Devastating Critique of Tony Blair
item.media:description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, left, at the White House with President George W. Bush in January 2003.
item.description: The 2.6-million-word inquiry, seven years in the making, is a verdict on the former prime minister, who joined George W. Bush in waging war.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: As Britain Takes Stock of Iraq War, Iraqis Grimly Assess Its Aftermath
item.media:description: A vigil on Wednesday for victims of the bombings in Baghdad on Sunday.
item.description: Sunday’s deadly bombing in Baghdad further brought into focus a panorama of suffering for which many blame the United States and Britain.
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN and TIM ARANGO
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Chilcot Report Reopens Wounds for Relatives of Fallen British Soldiers
item.media:description: The funeral of Pvt. Luke Daniel Simpson, a British soldier killed in a roadside bomb attack in Iraq, in 2007.
item.description: The publication of the inquiry into Britain’s decision to go to war in Iraq brought closure and calls for former Prime Minister Tony Blair to be held accountable.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Saudi Arabia, Blamed for Spawning Jihadists, Is Again Their Target
item.media:description: Worshipers gathered after a suicide bombing on Monday near the Prophet’s Mosque in Medina, Saudi Arabia.
item.description: After clamping down on Al Qaeda, the Saudi kingdom is again facing terrorism at home, including attacks on Monday and two dozen by ISIS in past two years.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: After Attacks on Muslims, Many Ask: Where Is the Outpouring?
item.media:description: Bangladeshis paid tribute on Sunday to the victims killed in the attack at the Holey Artisan Bakery in the diplomatic district of Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh.
item.description: In recent days, jihadists have killed more than 300 people in Turkey, Bangladesh, Iraq and Saudi Arabia, and many Westerners have responded with relative indifference.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Wigan’s Road to ‘Brexit’: Anger, Loss and Class Resentments
item.media:description: An English flag outside a house in a suburb of Wigan, a gritty northern English town where 64 percent of the population voted for “Brexit.”
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The Labour-dominated city voted “Leave” to jolt elites in London as well as in Brussels into restoring a lost world of secure jobs and communities.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: A Ukrainian Kleptocrat Wants His Money and U.S. Asylum
item.media:description: Pavlo Lazarenko, left, the former prime minister of Ukraine, with his son, Olexander Lazarenko, in 2004.
item.description: Pavlo Lazarenko, felon and former prime minister of Ukraine, is battling the United States for $250 million held offshore and for political asylum.
item.dc:creator: LESLIE WAYNE

item.title: Decision, Maybe Momentous, Nears in Case China Has Tried to Ignore
item.media:description: A frigate for the Chinese Navy patrolling near the Spratly Islands, in the South China Sea, in March. For more than three years, Beijing has refused to participate in the proceedings of an international tribunal considering a challenge to its expansive claims in the waters.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Beijing has rejected the work of an international tribunal considering its claims in the South China Sea. But with a decision expected soon, it seems to be getting nervous.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Cambodian Leader’s Family Is Profiting From His Position, Report Says
item.media:description: Prime Minister Hun Sen came to power in Cambodia in 1985 and is one of the world’s longest-serving leaders.
item.description: Relatives of Hun Sen have acquired shares in companies in nearly every sector of the economy, the human rights group Global Witness says.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Brazil Is Confronting an Epidemic of Anti-Gay Violence
item.media:description: Antonio Kvalo, 34, who created a website where Brazilians can log instances of anti-gay violence, said he had been motivated in part by his own experience.
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.description: Despite a storied image as a tolerant, open society, Brazil is, by some counts, the world’s deadliest place for sexual minorities.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: In Africa, Benjamin Netanyahu Looks for Friends, and U.N. Votes, for Israel
item.description: The Israeli prime minister is on a four-country tour, hoping to rebuild economic and strategic ties on a continent where his nation was once a major presence.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Strikes and Protests Bring Zimbabwe’s Capital to a Halt
item.media:description: The police detained a man suspected of looting on Wednesday in Harare, the Zimbabwean capital.
item.description: Zimbabweans stayed home Wednesday to protest the government’s handling of the deteriorating economy as discontent with President Robert Mugabe grows.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY MOYO and NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Disappearance of ex-Guantánamo Bay Prisoner Raises Alarms
item.media:description: Jihad Diyab, a citizen of Syria, was among half a dozen lower-level detainees resettled in Uruguay in December 2014.
item.description: Suggestions that a former detainee sent to Uruguay may have crossed the border into Brazil have prompted concerns on releasing detainees to other countries.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE and SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Boten Journal: The Rise, Fall and Possible Renewal of a Town in Laos on China’s Border
item.media:description: The main duty-free mall in Boten, Laos, converted from an old nightclub, is bereft of customers, its shelves of cigarettes and whiskey standing as still and pristine as museum exhibits.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: Boten, a onetime casino boomtown with thousands of visitors a month, is trying to come back, this time without gambling.
item.dc:creator: SEBASTIAN STRANGIO

item.title: Amid Crackdown, ISIS Warns of New Attacks in Bangladesh
item.media:description: Security forces blocked a street during the siege of a restaurant in Dhaka, Bangladesh, over the weekend.
item.description: The police are working to compile a list of young men who have vanished recently: the profile of the attackers in last weekend’s massacre.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK, MAHER SATTAR and GEETA ANAND
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Brother of Gunman in Paris Attacks, Recruited by ISIS, Is Sent to Prison
item.description: Karim Mohamed-Aggad, whose brother attacked the Bataclan concert hall, was sentenced to nine years for traveling to Syria to train as a militant fighter.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Pope Francis Meets Parents of Beau Solomon, U.S. Student Killed in Rome
item.media:description: Pope Francis meeting on Wednesday with Nick and Jodi Solomon, whose son’s body was found in the Tiber River this week.
item.media:credit: L'Osservatore Romano, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: The pope held a private, unscheduled meeting with Nick and Jodi Solomon, whose son was found dead in the Tiber River, the Vatican newspaper said.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Obama Imposes Sanctions on North Korean Leaders for Human Rights Abuse
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, in Pyongyang in May. Mr. Kim and 14 other senior North Korean officials were blacklisted by the United States.
item.description: The action against the dictator Kim Jong-un and 14 other leaders was taken after extrajudicial slayings, forced labor and torture, a U.S. official said.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Letter From Europe: In Soccer, Winners Are Clear; in ‘Brexit,’ Not So Much
item.media:description: People in London on Saturday protesting Britain’s vote to leave the European Union.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Across Europe, there are only two topics of conversation these days: the British vote to leave the European Union, and the European Championships.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Obama Says He Will Keep More Troops in Afghanistan Than Planned
item.description: The president said he expected to leave 8,400 American troops in Afghanistan until the end of his term. His last plan to lower the number set 5,500 as a target.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: What ‘Brexit’ Means for Pet Travel
item.media:description: The dog Daisy being carried by Charlotte Usher after arriving in England through the Channel Tunnel in 2000. The animal was one of 16 dogs and a cat to cross the Channel into Britain on the first day of the pet passport program that abolished Britain’s 100-year-old quarantine laws.
item.description: Yes, pets have passports. For now the European Union rules remain the same. But it is unclear what changes could come for Britons who travel with animals.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: Constitutional Conundrums, Real Estate Woes and Tory Voting
item.media:description: A demonstration on Saturday in London against Britain’s vote to leave the European Union.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Updates on the aftershocks of Britain’s June 23 referendum to leave the European Union.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Sentenced to 6 Years in Reeva Steenkamp Murder
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius arriving for sentencing in Pretoria, South Africa, on Wednesday.
item.description: A South African judge gave the athlete a shorter prison sentence than sought by prosecutors for the killing of his girlfriend in 2013.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: An Appreciation: Director Abbas Kiarostami Balanced Realism and Poetry, Censors and Viewers
item.media:description: Abbas Kiarostami, in 2015.
item.description: Mr. Kiarostami showed his fellow Iranian artists that, despite government restrictions and societal pressure, success, even international acclaim, was possible.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Belgian Court Jails Islamic State Cell Leaders for Foiled Plot
item.media:description: Belgian judge Pierre Hendrickx, center, presides over the trial of suspects in the foiled terrorist plot in the town of Verviers last year, at the Brussels Palace of Justice in Belgium on Tuesday.
item.description: The plot’s chief architect in the thwarted Belgian plot was also the on-the-ground coordinator in the Paris attacks in November.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Jewish Settlers, Attacked, Needed Help. A Palestinian Doctor Didn’t Hesitate.
item.media:description: Tehila Mark, left, at the funeral of her father, Rabbi Michael Mark, on Sunday. He was killed after a gunman fired on the family’s car in the West Bank. Tehila and her mother, Chavi, were also injured in the attack.
item.description: Dr. Ali Shroukh’s lifesaving efforts on a West Bank road have been hailed in Israel as inspirational in the face of months of increasing conflict.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: From Refugee Chefs, a Taste of Home
item.media:description: A dish at L’Ami Jean.
item.media:credit: Corentin Fohlen for The New York Times
item.description: Two French entrepreneurs are using food to try to change perceptions of immigrants.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Swedish Police Investigate Over 40 Reports of Rape and Groping at 2 Music Festivals
item.media:description: A police officer at a Bravalla Festival campsite in Norrkoping, Sweden, last weekend.
item.media:credit: Izabelle Nordfjell/TT News Agency, via Reuters
item.description: Dozens of women and girls, most under the age of 18, said they were sexually assaulted at the Bravalla and Putte i Parken festivals over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and CHRISTINA ANDERSON

item.title: Welsh Reject E.U., but Its Money Will Be Missed
item.media:description: An ailing economy in Newport, which voted to leave the European Union, is reflected in vacant storefronts and game parlors.
item.media:credit: Marco Kesseler for The New York Times
item.description: One of the looming questions in the aftermath of the “Brexit” vote is what happens to European Union aid flowing into places like Wales.
item.dc:creator: DANNY HAKIM

item.title: U.S. Moves to Limit Protections for Its Civilian Military Workers in Japan
item.media:description: An activist waved a sign saying “Don’t Rape Okinawa,” as American personnel walked toward a United States Marine base on the island in May.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The preliminary deal follows a bout of public outrage over several crimes linked to personnel and contractors employed by the American armed forces.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Lightning Ridge Journal: An Australian Town’s Rare Mix: Dinosaur Bones and Opalized Pine Cones
item.media:description: Pete Cooke, right, sifting through rock, and his brother Mick Cooke mine for opals in Lightning Ridge, Australia.
item.media:credit: Conor Ashleigh for The New York Times
item.description: Lightning Ridge, a town on the edge of the outback, is hoping visitors will flock to see such treasures at a new museum expected to be completed by 2020.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: China Says Hong Kong Bookseller Must Return or Face Parole Violation Penalties
item.media:description: Lam Wing-kee was one of five Hong Kong booksellers who disappeared last year.
item.description: Lam Wing-kee, who went public about his monthslong detention in mainland China, was one of five men connected with Mighty Current Media who disappeared last year.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: Conservative Backbiting; Labour Civil War; Welsh Regrets?
item.media:description: Home Secretary Theresa May in London on Tuesday. Ms. May has emerged as the clear front-runner among the five candidates seeking to replace David Cameron as leader of the Conservative Party.
item.description: A member of the Conservative Party was caught on camera sharing candid comments about his colleagues seeking the party’s leadership.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: French Inquiry Urges Changes to Intelligence Services in Light of Failures
item.description: Lawmakers who took part in the examination called on the authorities to merge overlapping and sometimes competing agencies.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Theresa May, the Steely, Steady Woman Who Might Lead Britain
item.media:description: Theresa May, the British home secretary and the front-runner to become Britain’s next prime minister, in London last week.
item.description: As lawmakers start voting to narrow the contenders for head of the party, Ms. May stands as a front-runner, with a reputation for seriousness and hard work behind her.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Rome Police Arrest Homeless Man in Murder of Beau Solomon, a U.S. Student
item.media:description: Forensic police officers scanned the banks of the Tiber in Rome where Beau Solomon’s body was found on Monday.
item.description: Mr. Solomon, of the University of Wisconsin-Madison, was found in the Tiber River with a head wound and blood on his shirt.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Nepal Investigating Indian Couple’s Claim of Climbing Everest
item.media:description: Satyarup Siddhanta, a climber based in Bangalore, India, holding in his right hand a photograph of him on Mount Everest, along with a version that he said an Indian couple had altered.
item.description: The couple are accused of doctoring photographs to suggest they reached the summit in May, becoming the first husband-and-wife team from India to do so.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Sinosphere: Amid Floods in China, Stranded Pigs Are Thrown a Lifeline
item.media:description: Li Zuming, a worker at a pig farm in Anhui Province, cried on Monday as he waded through floodwaters that threatened to engulf thousands of pigs.
item.description: Some of the thousands of swine that appeared destined for a watery end were rescued when a city’s government mobilized workers to help relocate them.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sinosphere: Ikea Under Fire in China After Limiting Dresser Recall to North America
item.media:description: Chinese shoppers trying out the merchandise at an Ikea store in Beijing.
item.description: The chests and dressers that are being recalled have been linked to the deaths of at least six children in the United States and Canada.
item.dc:creator: EMILY FENG

item.title: Sinosphere: China Cracks Down on News Reports Spread via Social Media
item.media:description: A villager in Sichuan Province reading his mobile phone. The government said it would punish websites that publish “directly as news reports unverified content found on online platforms such as social media.”
item.description: The Cyberspace Administration said it would punish sites that publish “directly as news reports unverified content found on online platforms,” but others see an effort to clamp down.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and VANESSA PIAO

item.title: After a Year, Rohingya Family Still Separated and Stranded
item.media:description: Hasinah Izhar performing a midday prayer last month in her family’s rented room in Penang, Malaysia.
item.media:credit: Rahman Roslan for The New York Times
item.description: Little has changed since an anguished mother told of fleeing Myanmar to seek refuge in Malaysia, with three children in tow — and one left behind.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees

item.title: What in the World: Why Finland’s Newborns Sleep in Cardboard Cribs
item.media:description: A baby in the Kela maternity package box, which is distributed to new parents in Finland.
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.description: “Baby boxes” were introduced in the 1930s to ensure that every infant had a safe place to nap (and that Mom got a checkup). And they worked.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: What in the World: The Lab Results Are In: Genes Might Be to Blame for Retrievers’ Obesity
item.media:credit: Illustration by Lia Kantrowitz; photographs by Africa Studio, Best photo studio, Petr Salinger, Phich Keers, Hurst Photo, Dojdis, stockcreations/Shutterstock
item.description: Labrador retrievers’ renowned gluttony and resulting obesity may be due to a faulty gene that regulates appetite and helps sense how much fat is stored.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: What in the World: Proud to Live in a Town Called Dildo
item.description: Residents of Dildo, Newfoundland, are eager to dispel misguided notions about where their town got its name.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Frexit? Dexit? Auxit? No Way. Britain Is Special.
item.media:description: Revelers sang the national anthem during Queen Elizabeth II’s 90th birthday celebrations in London last month.
item.description: The island and the Continent have a long, rocky — and unique — history.
item.dc:creator: ALINA POLYAKOVA and NEIL FLIGSTEIN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Chilcot Report: How Tony Blair Sold the War
item.description: The report condemns Britain’s reckless warmongers, yet omits the true cost — Iraq’s unnumbered dead.
item.dc:creator: CARNE ROSS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Editorial: Fighting ISIS as It Shifts Tactics
item.description: The threat requires a complex response, including better cooperation among the region’s nations and the United States.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
